displayName.text: The Renfrew Center for Eating Disorders - New York, NY

formattedAddress: 38 E 32nd St 10th floor, New York, NY 10016, USA

authorAttributions.displayName: The Renfrew Center for Eating Disorders - New York, NY
The Renfrew Center for Eating Disorders - New York, NY

adrFormatAddress: 38 E 32nd St 10th floor, New York, NY 10016-3318, USA

originalText.text: I had the worst experience here and was sent to residential. I strongly recommend looking into other programs in the city that are not so behaviorally focused. The Renfrew Center is very punitive and antiquated in their approach to eating disorders. I don’t recommend anyone go here for treatment, regardless of which eating disorder they’re battling.

text.text: I had the worst experience here and was sent to residential. I strongly recommend looking into other programs in the city that are not so behaviorally focused. The Renfrew Center is very punitive and antiquated in their approach to eating disorders. I don’t recommend anyone go here for treatment, regardless of which eating disorder they’re battling.

originalText.text: I can truly give 5 stars to the Renfrew Center, NYC site. They are fully staffed, and the staff genuinely care about the full wellbeing of the patient. I have also seen the NYC site become more knowledgeable about the impact of trauma on EDs, to better help and understand the needs of some patients. The dietitians use a Health At Every Size approach, and are extremely knowledgeable and supportive. The therapists each have different approaches, but all understand the importance of connection and using skills for long term recovery. This location also utilizes art and drama therapy to create a different path forward to recovering. I can never thank the staff at this site enough for teaching me that I am capable of recovery, and that I deserve it. Thank you Renfrew, for everything.

originalText.text: lowkey traumatized me and made my eating disorder worse lol. they grouped me when I was in my early teens with middle aged women and talked about inappropriate topics like alcoholism when I didn't even fully understand what it was. they make you eat so much more food than what other treatment centers and experts recommend and usually over 3000cals+  which is unhealthy for everyone even traumatizing recovering patients. the therapists were flakey and they switched my therapist every week because they left for "personal reasons" there so I would have to explain over and over again the same uncomfortable topics and not even get the "therapy treatment" they advertise because they would all leave so you couldn't even get the chance to be comfortable with talking to them.

originalText.text:
Pros:
- Worksheet templates

Cons:
- Overrepresentation of white women and underrepresentation of women of color.

- IOP evening groups felt over crowded and the turnover made it clear that priority one for Renfrew is revenue rather than quality care.

- Question of efficacy of Renfrew's group activities. They seemed thrown together and to not follow the syllabus.

- Weekly therapy vs Bi-weekly nutrition treatment seemed backward to me, considering the likelihood that many folks came into treatment with a clinical support team.

- False advertising on their website. Renfrew NYC did not have a Jewish (faith-based) clinician to incorporate Jewish framework into treatment.

- Clinicians and staff overshared information during group sessions, such as frustration with their colleagues and/or Renfrew culture.

- Poor administration management - the financial coordinator left upon my exit from treatment and since, I've been overcharged and I am having to have it fixed.

- I would not recommend Renfrew NYC to a friend seeking caring, anti-racist, eating disorder treatment.

- False advertising on their website. Renfrew NYC did not have a Jewish (faith-based) clinician to incorporate Jewish framework into treatment.

- Clinicians and staff overshared information during group sessions, such as frustration with their colleagues and/or Renfrew culture.

- Poor administration management - the financial coordinator left upon my exit from treatment and since, I've been overcharged and I am having to have it fixed.

originalText.text: I am giving a star because I don’t have the option to not give one. I have never encountered such a horrible place like this in my life. I have never felt so discouraged and unmotivated like this place made me feel. I was at an in patient program and they referred me here. I am grateful that I got to meet genuine patients. But the staff is horrible. The only person that I don’t have anything bad to say about is Jill Hartman. This facility needs to look into Colleen Wagner. It still mind blows me that, that callous woman is a psychologist and that, that is who they have running the place. She called me sick, told me I look sick, that I was filled with excuses. If you have COVID you are treated the worst. I have not been able to attend because I have COVID and have been testing positive with Pcr even after the two weeks. Due to their rules I need to be negative. I voiced that virtual is a challenge for me. I had an emergency with my phone and she completely disregarded me and hung up on me multiple times. I will report this to every avenue that I can this way no other patient feels how she made me feel. This toxic encounter caused me an anxiety attack. I also felt discriminated many times because I am Hispanic. I have seen my white peers be treated better than I have. She used reasons for disqualifying me under lies. Please do not attend here. Go anywhere else but here.
